J6RsgkBIrJ226JzPQLHg9w.text: The food is really great. I have that to say. The jap chae is almost exactly how I like it, not quite umami enough but pretty close; the bibimbap is good; other selected items have the right flavors and textures.But the service is below par. When I go to a restaurant I expect to have a single server plus a seating host and a busser. Here, I had to constantly attract the attention of whomever happened to be near me (I was sitting near the register) and had at least 5 people. And that's not including the ones who looked up and smiled but did nothing. Because of this, I felt largely ignored. It took waaaay too long to even bring me a glass of water.The decor, as everyone mentioned, is nice -- except the only place for single diners to sit is at the bar seating up against the window. And for some reason it is always cold, and the chairs are uncomfortable and heavy. I walked in and saw a number of empty six-seater tables and asked to have one (because I had eaten at the window before) and I knew it would be cold, yet they refused (I was also wet from the rain). I saw a number of couples sharing the communal six-seater tables and wondered why I couldn't have been seated at one. Oddly enough, this happened the last time when I went with a friend as well. Then I was completely forgotten about.This place could be really good if it gets its act together.

6ZIeYdii-WbhTjAlUgrZng.text: I came here a while ago with a couple of friends and my girlfriend. I really liked the decor inside the restaurant, it gives it a really different feel to it which seperates itself from the other Korean restaurant in London.We enjoyed the food although I found the portions quite small but I expected that from the look of the restaurant. The bill for 4 people came to £80 but we did order a fair bit more because of the smaller portions.This place is worth a visit and I would definately go back again.

zbFd2cbtDV9ZxFR-V3dFNQ.text: I was one of the participants of the recent VIQ event at Kimchee. As anyone can tell from my user name, I am a huge fan of Korean cuisine. I had not made it to Kimchee yet and was really looking forward to my first visit as I had heard lots about it from other foodies.The first impressions were good if unusual for a Korean restaurant  the main restaurant has a Wagamama-style layout with an open kitchen and long bench-style seating. After a few minutes in the waiting area we were greeted by Adam, the restaurant manager, and led downstairs to the new dining area. The room had a much more intimate feel to it than the upstairs area, with smaller tables and lots of dark wood; very nice and stylish.After being introduced to Graham, who was our bartender for the evening, we were served a Korean plum wine with our first dish, Prawn Mari, which was a kind of summer roll but the spinach, and the sesame oil used to season it, was a very typical Korean combination. I've never seen such rolls on the menu of a Korean restaurant before so this was an interesting start to our taster menu. Next up was the Pa Jeon which tasted good but I must agree with chopstix2steaknives and would have preferred it to be a bit lighter. But nevertheless, the taste was good. It was served with Bek Seju, a Korean rice wine. I had never tried Bek Seju before as I usually stick to tea when I have Korean food. I must say that I found it to be a very acquired taste and smell but hey, at least I tried it.Other dishes, in no particular order, were Yang Yuem Chicken, Crab Tuigim, Gogi Mandu and Pa Jeon. This were served with Mak Geolli, which I found to be much more palatable than the Bek Seju!We were also served two very traditional Korean dishes, namely Yuk Hwae and Kimchee (also spelled Kimchi ;)The Yuk Hwae was very good and one of the better ones I have tasted but it would have been even more refreshing if the meat had been a bit colder. I also liked the challenge of mixing everything together as this is usually done by the waiting staff.The Kimchi is made from scratch and you could tell  it was not only very good and authentic; it was also heavily fermented, which is hard to find in restaurants as they usually serve a 'fresher' version of Kimchi. This was certainly the best Kimchi I've had in a restaurant.Our evening was rounded off by lovely cocktails and a we were given very handy guide to Korean restaurants in England which I will doubtlessly put to good use.Altogether I think that Kimchee is on to something good; some dishes are a fresh take on Korean food but it does not let down with the more traditional dishes. I would have loved to try a few more traditional dishes such as a Korean stew, Jap Chae or Bulgogi and hope that the opportunity will arise to visit Kimchee again. I was also impressed by the quality of the tableware, which is apparently imported from Korea. The staff are passionate about what they do and seem determined to introduce Korean food to as many people as possible. And the queues that form at the door of Kimchee every evening indicate that they are well on their way to doing just that.

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom

HTF9TOT0iTqAonkjxNIfAg.text: So another guest of the VIQ event..the bar has been set high  this was exactly the kind of experience a VIQ event should be  sampling something new and exciting with generous and informative hosts.The venue is a great mix between the traditional and modern  they work hard here with the authentic touches and that is to be admired. The ground floor restaurant was busy and buzzing  we were downstairs in a private space about to be launched to the general public. Heavily styled with traditional touchescool and chic So Kimchee (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ki…) - a traditional fermented Korean dish made of vegetables with a variety of seasonings  made on the premises  still not really certain if this is pickled or fermented or both  their version was cabbage with chilli paste  I would say an acquired taste  not sure I could do a whole dish but as a component ingredient in other dishes it definitely adds a kick. (See photo below) The food was consistently of great quality  I think the fried dishes were the most successful - crab was very good and I know my kids would love the chicken dishes. This is a menu to savour and explore  my first experience of korean food  it won't be my last (See photo below) The real star of the show was the Yuk Hwae (above) - similar to a beef tartare  high quality raw beef with sweet pear and cucumber  served with sesame oil and seeds with an egg yolkcarnivore heaven.We explored the drinks menu in tandem with the food menu  I would pick the plum wines when I return  others a bit more of a challenge  need to train my palette to embrace the new.The real test is would I go backan easy yes  with friends or family.in a group with a pile of dishes to sample and share - perfect social fare. And a big thank you for the Korean restaurant guide  a really nice touch!

5c4ikcet8VYDO2OvUydHZA.text: Kimchee is a new restaurant that opened up in Holborn. It took over the ex-Matsuri site that had a fire incident last year which it seems that they never managed to recover from.It was another ladies' catch up dinner and the opening of Kimchee was perfect timing. On the day we went, it was actually Opening Day 2.Even at 8pm, the place was jam packed and we waited for 40 minutes to get a table. While waiting, there was a gentleman who asked if he could join us. Sorry mister, ladies only and trying to cut the queue is a no no! When you get to the front of the queue, a lady kindly invited us to wait inside at a scenic garden patch of stone pebbles and fountain with a wall of Korean characters glowing against a dark setting. Turn your head and you are greeted by the grill section where you could see the chefs busily grilling away.We were finally called and upon being seated, we were informed that any skewers orders will take around 20 minutes due to how busy the kitchen was. We quickly placed our orders as most of us were starving by then. While waiting for our orders, we looked around and it was a huge place. I almost did not notice that there were 2 sections to the place that had a cage like wall dividing both sections. Most tables have seats of 6 with bar-like benches along the side for lone or double diners. I liked the decor with the lanterns motif used for the lights; the whole place had a streamlined unassuming posh feel to it.Kimchee -The crunchy texture and sweetness of the cabbage is more prominent in this version with the heat of the chilli hitting you only right at the end. Not overly spicy which is good for the non-kimchee lovers but bad if you like it super spiced!Sukju Namul - A cold dish of bean sprouts in sesame oil & garlic dressing. This was quite normal and a good one to order if you like bean sprouts.  Yuk Hwae £- One of my favourites in Korean cuisine. Yuk Hwae comprises of thinly sliced raw beef that is semi-frozen with pears that have been sliced to the same length and size as the beef to bring out the refreshing sweetness. Topped with sesame sauce and egg yolk to give an aromatic creamy balance. The Yuk Hwae was one of the better ones I've had in London. It is such an amazing summer dish when made right. The one from Kimchee was good, the sweetness of the pear slices paired well with the beef. The dressing was light with just the right amount of sesame to accentuate the flavours. The beef slices could have been set to a more semi-frozen state so that it gives that crunchy texture but this is just nitpicking here. I am already happy that I did not get one that has been drowned in sesame (so many places do that) such that you don't get all the other elements that make this so good.Jap Chae - I really like the Jap Chae in Asadal which is quite close by, actually that was our Plan B if we couldn't get in to Kimchee. We all loved the Jap Chae here. Sesame oil and soy sauce that has clinged to each and every strand of glass vermicelli noodles, delicious!Pa Jeon - There were 3 Korean pancakes on the menu but we decided to go for the traditional version which is made with spring onions and seafood mix, served with soy and chilli sauce on the side. The pancake was too doughy and it didn't have that slight crisp exterior. The flavours were drowned out by the too generous proportion of the doughy batter.Spicy calamari - Spicy calamari was quite ordinary. The calamari itself was good but the batter was not deep fried enough and was a tad bland. The vegetables that came with it were good though. Crab Tuigim - This was quite a disappointment. Deep fried soft shell crab should be crispy with the oil mixed into the juices of the crab and batter for that oh-so-good deep fried taste. Kimchee's version was not deep fried enough and the soft shell crab was still quite fresh because of that. None of us liked this one.Bulgogi - Bulgogi is another favourite that people like to order and we were no exception. Described as thinly sliced beef that has been marinated in a blend of fruits, soy sauce, sesame oil, black pepper, onions and garlic, this was GOOD! Tenderly soft and juicy.

Gdir7gBBkC2s1iFUPHvP6Q.text: Food was good, although the starters were really small in portion, better order an extra main course to share amongst each other.It took very long to order and you got food before your drinks were there, although the decor was nice. Oh and half the things we intended to order were already out.I'd say the concept is similar to Wagamamas, but the service at W's is better.

HwU6KKI52r6FVgqvK9e7kA.text: Pretty cool and modern space. The food is delicious but somehow I felt it was a bit westernized. Still a great choice! You can sign up for Zapper and save £5 off the first time!

6Byhq1MU0z1mlBZIOjPMLA.text: I don't suppose this is the most authentic Korean place you can find in London, but it certainly is a lot better than a lot of the other noodle-y places in Central. I had the seafood noodle soup which came with a good amount and mixture of seafood and was nicely spicy as advertised. My dining companion had the bibimbap which was served in the sizzling pot with the raw egg on top. We both really enjoyed our dinners. We're definitely not Korean food experts, but the dishes were tasty, fresh and generous in size.The service was a little chaotic - the queuing system was manned by a girl who had no idea what she was doing and  lot of parties left because people that had clearly come in after them were seated beforehand. We were really only seated within 15 mins because we were quite assertive and flagged the fact that others were seated ahead of us.The seats are also packed very tightly togeather, so you really don't have much space to get comfy and it's certainly not somewhere to go to linger over drinks and dinner.Would be 4 stars if it was little more relaxed and the service less frenetic, but the food is good and it's a good price in for such a central location.

cFAOnb5y40NT83dwFMdhdA.text: Normally I can overlook bad service if the food makes up for it. Unfortunately It was hard to decide which was worse at this place. The service was deplorable and the food was worse than the takeaway branch up the road. God knows what the Korean customers at the next table thought of this place, they must have been too drunk on badly poured drinks to care... Save your money and try one of the places around centre point, or even Bibigo!

8S3qR8O6w1Shr4_a0pbQ5A.text: I ordered a Beef Bibimbap, Chicken Mandu, and "Korean tea" (some fruit-infused normal tea I think). It was delicious, although the portions were decidedly on the small side, especially for what you pay for (heh I'm jus gona, like, ignore my bill and focus on the pleasant food coma vibe/high). So, it's not exactly as cheap/whoagh as SoCal Korean food, but I'm a happy camper since I got my fix tonight.

FekTEQ9Uj5OJVWo0w-LvNQ.text: I went to Kimchee this past Friday as I've had a craving for Korean food (somewhat strangely, since I don't usually eat it that much!) and this was nearby a friend's office.We were seated quite quickly - maybe because it's vacation season - although the service thereafter was a bit erratic and confusing, with many different servers taking orders and delivering things at different times.  I will also note that the prices are very very reasonable - my friend and i ordered three starters, two mains, and three drinks between us and the total with service was less than £25 each! Bargain.That said, the food was not absolutely outstanding as I've come to expect from other Korean establishments in London.  Part of this was my fault - I ordered basic bibimbap (rather than dolsat bibimbap) so it seemed distinctly cold.  My friend's pork bulgogi on the other hand was tender and tasty.  The starters were also great - although I do not recall the exact names at the moment, we had a beef spring roll, prawns with chili sauce and the best thing of all, the little omelet.  Delicious!  I'm not sure if I would go out of my way to hit Kimchee again (I would prefer Soju, Arirang or others) but in the neighborhood, it would be a relatively inexpensive and tasty option in a pleasant and buzzy atmosphere.

XG1s29dQC3g3hPU5APfGRw.text: I attended Qypes first VIQ event at Kimchee yesterday evening and had a great time. I loved the design of the restaurant and the fact that we were entertained in our own private eating area down stairs. From start to finish, we were treated very well, especially by our host for the event.Kimchee spoiled us, as each drink we received, soon followed a side dish from the menu. My favorites were the fried dishes which consisted of; pa jeon (Korean style pancakes with seafood, crab tuigim (soft shell crab) and kanpoogi (chicken in a rice basket).At the end we received a guide to Korean restaurants in England, which I though was very nice, since they were trying to promote the countries cuisine, rather than think of others as competition.

U0UQqgIbrXYfZlITQscUlw.text: This restaurant constantly offers deals and vouchers on their website. A couple months ago, I visited the restaurant using 'Lazy Sundays' voucher in which I got  50% 0ff Food (excluding drinks) on Sunday. So if you'd like to visit this place yourself, it's best to watch out for new deals on their website. Despite some bad reviews, this restaurant seems to be very popular. I was there just a few minutes after it opened for lunch. There was a line of  customers queuing! and the place was already full! I thought it's because of the promotion but my friend who visited this place before has told me after ward that this place's known for a long queue. Therefore, not the best place for a large group. You would get a table quickly if it's a group of two or three people. They only take a reservation for 10 or more people. I have to say that they've got one thing right which is the decoration and ambiance. The place is spacious and looks very modern-Asian. The tables and chairs were quite big, so you get a plenty of space without having to sit uncomfortable close with other customers. The menu looked impressive and there're a lot of cocktails as well.The food's presentation was good. It wasn't messy and some efforts have been put into the dish. However, Pa Jeon was a bit cold  and some dishes didn't come with rice. I had 'seafood and soft tofu Jigae' and ordered rice separately. The soup was spicy and peppery. It's served hot and it was full of flavour. However, the seafood was quite small in there. I tried soju cocktails. I personally found it tasted a bit like a cold medicine. It didn't have a good balance like what a good drink should have. Overall, it would be best to visit during weekday and not with a large group.

TjkSwY7P4rdNrNHjrNyxFA.text: Came here with a friend for dinner after work. I had never had Korean food before, but as a Thai-lover, I didn't find it as tasty!Nevertheless, the service was impeccable and the decor was really cool. The only downside is it is quite loud in there so it is hard to have a normal conversation.They are normally very busy after work hours (we had to queue for a table) so I would recommend coming before 6pm. Also the prices were quite expensive.

95qmDRVlFyhLzedZz36YMw.text: Kimchee restaurant on High Holborn. Before getting into the details, I will give you the bottom line: worth a try because the Korean flavours are authentic and good, but expect to pay prices that are too high and service to be BAD. Food: I'm not Korean, but my very first job was working in a Korean restaurant, so I know a thing or two about Korean food. The flavours are spot on--i tried the bibimbap (mix rice dish), BBQ bulgogi, kimchee and the iced plum tea. The rice was just okay, but the rest was tasty! Price: for a limited time, Kimchee is offering 50% off the food (not drinks)l. If these were the normal prices, it would be so worth coming here on a regular basis BUT, it's not. £8 for a small portion of BBQ (without rice or other traditional accompliments) is NOT really worth it. Kimchee, their namesake, is £3 on the regular menu! (Most Korean restaurants give this away for free because it is so inexpensive, and is akin to ketchup; something that is on every Korean table.) Service: where do I start? The hostess we first encountered spoke very poorly, so I misunderstood her and inadvertently cut the line. Instead of coming over to clarify herself, she started yelling at me saying--"you're very rude. You're very rude to cut in front of everyone." I stared at her and asked if she was being serious; she was. When I asked to speak to her manager, she started pleading "no, no, no!". This is the face of your new, expensive restaurant? Really? Time to reconsider! The waitress was nice, but also inefficient as we never saw her again after placing our initial order. In summary, worth a try while they are taking half off the food, but once that's over, not sure i will come back!

Qpeic32ctSfoPTu33y9CAA.text: LOVE this place! Great food and really good prices. Pro's: hip decor. Friendly & efficient service. Great sized portions. Cons: loud. There's a line during the weekend nights (but this is obviously typical for London). Definitely recommend to others!

YKTgezJ_KgLs4vqIJykw0g.text: Not sure why this place gets only 3 stars on average. I like it quite a lot. The food is good and fresh, service always spot on when I go there and they have the yummiest green tea ice cream ever!

Tw4uxitqHuHvihxUS6iJWg.text: I LOVE THIS PLACE!  From the decor to the food to the prices, all in, a wonderful restaurant.1. Food: Ordered the dolsat bibimbap, the bulgogi, kim chee, and a couple of other appetizers.  Everything was delicious.  While the drinks may sound interesting, they weren't impressive.  I'd say the portions are a bit on the small side, but great value (dishes are 7 - 9 pounds each).2. Service: Inconsistent.  Food took a while to appear, and we were largely ignored by the team.  After requesting drinks with several different waiters, we finally got them.3. Atmosphere: Soothing, open, and casual.  Dark minimalist tables placed next to an open air kitchen.  Usually attracts corporate personnel.

SvllkYcttY-VCw3GWKyg4Q.text: This new place is really near my job so I stopped in for lunch.  The staff was speaking Korean to me and it seemed really artificial considering myself as well as everyone on staff was obviously not Korean.  I ordered the sundubu jigae (soft tofu soup) and there serving size was impressive, but it wasn't served with rice so I had to order that separately.  The dish was pretty authentic tasting although way overdone with sea creatures (sundubu jigae is normally served with a few clams and prawns for taste).  Overall this place seemed pretty contrived and overpriced.  I'd go out of my way to hit up Soju in Soho instead.

I6pSLgvqot62wN6guuHloA.text: Pretty good night last night for our first Qype VIQ event. I've never actually been able to taste so many different dishes & drinks in one evening! Everything was deliciously prepared & really tasty. Unlike T, the steak tartare was most likely my favourite dish:) To top it up, we got the luxury of having the General Manager detailing every dish one by one with an explanation on origins and preparation.The four stars for now only reflects the fact that I didn't actually come to dinner at this place yet properly. That is not to say this will not change as I already have it on my radar for my next girlfriends night out monthly reunion and will update this review accordingly soon.

WPjwqfht6Iq1uXHkCLp93w.text: I happened upon this place while walking around on a Sunday evening. Not being from London, I didn't realize that many places to eat would be closed, but I was lucky enough to find Kimchee. It was pretty packed! So I was definitely excited and decided to try it out.I was seated very quickly and given a menu, and ordered a Bibimbap with raw beef and a coke pretty quickly without much issue, which came out surprisingly quickly. So far, so good! It was served in a hot stone bowl and the side of sweet chili definitely gave it a tasty touch. Overall, I liked it! But... I have a few concerns with the service. As a important side note, I did dine alone, as I was traveling by myself.There might have a been a slight confusion as to who my server was... I remember being halfway through my meal when a party of two next to me was seated. They ordered, ate, and paid, AND left all in a timely manner. I was sitting there one my phone with an obviously empty bowl and coke cup/bottle for forever! What other visual cues do you need to realize that a customer is done...? Thus, they came in midway of my meal, and was able to leave well before I did... By the time I left, I realized that I had been there for an hour and a half - with half of that time being on my phone and trying to flag time someone to get me my check and my change... Watching other groups of patrons getting serviced and leaving without issue didn't make me a happy customer... At least the food was good.

cLbfYEPFJKO9wb3epaPjRQ.text: Well, you've got the place for authentic korean food here hence, the reason for the peak in prices. I wouldn't say it's too pricey, but for the portion provided I would say it's abit overpriced but hell yes I'd definately come back.I must say, I had a lovely dinner here with my friends. The must-order dish is "bibimbap" (you know what they say if you haven't ordered this, you're not dining korean food). The dish consists of rice in the middle topped with raw egg and you have variety of raw veggies around the dish. For chicken lovers who loves to spice things up a little, "yang yeum chicken" is the one! the chicken is lightly battered and served with sweet chilli sauce and it tastes heavenly. the outer layer of chicken being slightly cripsy but as you break through you get the very smooth texture inside ! For kimchi lovers, here at Kimchee they provide good quality kimchi ! note here, it's quite spicy so you might wanna order only a plate first and try out. the other dish I had was "jap chae" where it's glass noodles stir fried with meat and veggies. I reallyyy like this dish as the texture of the glass noodles are very gluey and you get just the right amount of saltiness from all the combinations. Finally.. Desserts! I have to say...I'M IN LOVE with the ICECREAM here. they provide a variety of ice cream options. I ordered the black sesame icecream and red bean icecream and was hooked with the flavours! It's not too milky but and you get the taste of sesame coming through and for the red bean icecream, you can taste the subtle red bean through the icecream. Overall, great place to dine! Nice, big and clean place to dine in but it gets crowded very easily and the tables are too close together in my opinion. You're presented with a variety of authentic korean dishes on the menu you'd be twined up not knowing what to order! but that's the experience I'm always looking for. The feeling of so many food options...whats not to love. ;)   ps. The seats fill up really fast during lunch and dinner times so you'd wanna hurry there before those peak times or just make a booking with them to ensure you've got your place.

M20f4YibLvrhoCnShBzaLg.text: Interesting decor, good food, friendly service and reasonable prices. I went with a group of eight and was able to try a little bit of what everyone ordered. The kimchee is definitely an acquired taste. The seafood bibimbap is tastier that the fried and raw beef one. The Udon noodle with soy sauce was a bit too sweet for my taste. My favourite was the jajang myeon with pork and seafood. I ordered the pork belly with a side of broccoli and was happy with the thin slices and tasty dip, but you need to order rice or a side dish. Icecream was good as well.

uvE295YYpyFwyneeWbr3Gg.text: Tried the spicy fried rice and fish cake. It is not a big quantity but it tastes really good. I like it and bibimbap is also good. I like this restaurant and cannot forget the person with whom I had lunch together.

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom

DjUSiLP-Rgb1oIadVmHGdQ.text: Very bad service, a 老外waiter, he gave us a super tiny seat, I should say it was kind like sandwich seat. And we saw there are some other available table, so we asked if we could change to those, unexpected answer is No, and that waiter said: this is good for me! such rude answer and attitude! This is fucking no way in New York! But it's ok in UK!真是他媽的好笑！太欺負人了！是老外，爛韓國餐廳！

QxMsRN2Do___NCfXzsbnGA.text: Went there for lunch - it was very busy with local business people. I had a soup set and it was descent - it is not a destination restaurant by any measure but for sure a good option if you are in the area. It is ran by  a group of korean ladies and it feels quite homey and cozy. Would definitely stop by if you are in the area and craving korean!

IRX_Py6hUXxKO7x_MprjyQ.text: Consistently great quality of food worth the price. The long lines in front of the door at busy times (despite the recent expansion of the restaurant) should speak for themselves. And don't leave without the green tea ice cream!

XGq1tzgqgicFiAnj12D5LA.text: Went here with my girlfriend and 4 friends. The decor is very nice and modern. Cleverly setting the diners away from the busy road.The chap that served us was very good for suggestions and checking the food would suit us. Service is quite quick and in the Wagamama style of it arrives when it arrives.The presentation is superb and the food is very tasty. A varied menu should cater for everyone.Had a really nice meal here and will be going back a few times I'm sure.

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom

ZGNsK6okENUfRbA8m_bdhQ.text: This place is swanky! As far as presentation is concerned, this would a nice place to take a date (and affordable too). It is, however, busy and loud and I didn't love my food. Nothing really wrong with it, just meh and not too filling. There was some foul up with my roommate's order and her food came about 40 minutes after ours. At least they were pleasant enough about it (easy for me to say, I wasn't the one with the grumbling stomach). They do have a yummy dessert of chocolate rice cakes you should try if you go though.

YwuQ9aupw8s_njrR8YR5tw.text: I used to love Kimchee but they falied me in a big way tonight, and it's such a shame.I don't think I've ever gotten decent service here, and I was willing to overlook it with the 50% off Sunday's deal. But when I'm paying full price, it starts to hurt when the servers take ages to get to you, forget things and generally lose you in the hustle and bustle. I very clearly stated (and the waitress repeated back to me) no egg in my bibimbap - so when it arrived with egg, I sent it back, explaining to her that I was allergic. To my surprise and horror they brought it straight back and it was apparent that they'd just taken the egg out of my food and handed it back to me (!!). That is NOT acceptable, I don't care how good the food tastes. They refused to make eye contact with me again after that and I had to actually get up and bring the plate over to the chefs, who kindly remade it for me.So, final verdict: I would only go here with the discount. It's not worth the full price.

4MOjkoSFUEVRuxNTjFTmow.text: I'm not sure what happened, but this place has gone waaay downhill since it's opened.Let's start with the food - BLAND and frankly some dishes are tasteless. I'll give them credit for the raw beef tartare which is good - mix in the raw egg it's actually quite a tasty dish. Then you have the 'dolsot bibimbap' which doesn't taste of much. It doesn't matter which you get - chicken, raw beef, beef - tastes the same. In fact I've started ordering tofu bibimbap because I like the sweet teriyaki sauce that they drizzle (at least it brings some flavour?). Word of caution, the raw beef overcook easily because the pieces are so thinly sliced - you're better of having them cook it for you or risk having cremated/dry beef to go with your rice. The chicken/vegetable dumplings again are bland and the filling is mushy. Bleugh. Aren't these supposed to be freshly pan fried given the 10-15 minute wait time for food? My food arrived cold. The tofu is fine - you have a slightly chewy batter that is fried, and then teriyaki-esque sauce is drizzled over. Wouldn't order it again as an 'appetiser' if I didn't have the 50% discount. My friends have had the pancakes before - not very appetising in my opinion.Service. So we were in a rush, and I ordered dolsot bibimbap (I know it always comes quickly), and my friend ordered a selection of raw beef tartare, COLD noodles, pancakes. The server then tells us that the bibimbap will only take 15 minutes, while my friend's food will take 30-40 minutes and that she should consider ordering something else. We looked at him a bit surprised - cold noodles and beef tartare take 30-40 minutes, whereas a bibimbap only takes 15? We asked him how long the noodles would take thinking it was the pancakes that was the hold-up. Surprise, the noodles were the hold-up. She ended up ordering some soup dish instead but can someone explain to me how cold noodles with slices of cucumber, carrots and a sauce takes 30-40 minutes to prepare?! Food arrives, and they got her order wrong - kimchee pancakes turned into some chive/seafood pancake looking thing. Sent it back. We finish eating, and then it takes 10 minutes to finally make eye contact with someone (a very difficult task at this place). After asking for the bill, it took another 15 minutes to actually get the bill. Add on another 15 minutes for them to get the card machine and by this point I was beyond fed up. No extra tip for them, we got up and left. Highly doubtful that I'll ever come back. Maybe I'll consider it if I have the 50% discount voucher, but I'm not sure if I can put up with the service and borderline bad food. Yelpers, just don't come here. Tottenham Court Road nearby has much better Korean food.

a6QX6jW5DlsIfNwXH2Eidg.text: Great vibes, good food, great decor as well.  Very  attentive staff. Vegetarian friendly as well

zFe5xAbOU48bZGaLIyLxZA.text: Lunch at Kimchee was alright. I popped in with a new friend, hoping for a different kind of cuisine to tempt my taste buds, and here's what I discovered:The good:- lots of menu options- authentic presentation of food; not sure how authentic the food was, but it was goodThe bad: - feeling a bit like sardines as the restaurant filled up for lunch- pretty expensive for the portion sizesThe ugly:- an inability to get our server to bring the bill, despite asking twice and asking another server twice as wellSo it's, like I said, alright. Not the strongest showing I've had at a local restaurant in the Holborn area, but certainly not the worst. Maybe it just wasn't my day, but unfortunately I probably won't be back, with so many other options I know I love nearby.

JoW5KvrvQVhWvki1Oo3ytg.text: I have never had a good experience in Korean restaurants in London, and sadly, Kimchee was a disappointment as well. The food is really, really overpriced - like, I would understand if all the ingredients had to be shipped from Korea, but most of the ingredients you can get in London as well. Like some previous reviewer said, all the dishes are overly sweet, perhaps to suit Londoners' tastes, but it's far from being authentic. If I had to make a comparison I wouldn't even pay three pounds for their bulgogi dishes if I were in Korea.

sKcGkteLtO6M6LX8b31jmw.text: I've visited the take away branches and loved them. I think they are the best Asian quick bite chain in London to have sprung up. I was pleased to stumble upon there sit in table service restaurant by Holborn station. I've only started being a Korean food fan in the last year as I was so in love with Japanese, Thai and Vietnamese to ever really give Korean food the attention it needed and deserved! I'm am now a Korean food lover !

SaihXwhZHVSLn44ZsYphHQ.text: After moving from the US, I've missed authentic Korean food courtesy of my mom and grandma and have found the options in central London limited. So when Kimchee opened a few months back I was there to test my taste buds its opening month. The verdict then: Food was okay and service needed improvement but I wrote off my mediocre experience to opening month jitters. I returned 3 more times since then and I'm happy to report that the service has improved. I speak Korean fluently so appreciated the greeting efforts by non-Korean staff at the door. The staff are always friendly and I've seen them offer suggestions to customers new to Korean cuisine. That's worth a star.If you're not new to Korean food, then I would recommend trying the ggak du gi (radish) and shee geum chi (spinach) side dishes. I also really liked their kim chee jjigae (stew with tofu, onions, scallions, kimchee, and choice of pork or seafood) - it's  just the right combination of filling, spicy, and refreshing.The reason why this place is only 3 stars is because1) In korean restaurants in NYC and California, you are always provided with an endless supply and choice of side dishes, especially the staple kimchee. Here, they charge for each side dish.2) You also have to pay for rice, but I've seen Thai places charge for rice alongside curry dishes as well so it may be a London thing.3) The portions are small.This isn't the best Korean restaurant I've ever been to, but combined with the clean decor, friendly staff, and picking the right entree - I'll be back for sure.

fE955MTsg8AVK6B7OFdApg.text: I love being introduced to new places, and being taken to Kimchee on a VIQ event felt extra special. The manager made everyone feel very welcome and personally introduced a taster menu of smaller tapas-style dishes. I can truthfully say that I probably wouldn't have chosen a single one of those and therefore missed out on the great variety of textures and flavours typical of the cuisine. Each course was accompanied by a speciality drink  again, I would have probably just stuck to the more familiar choice of beer or wine. Some of the flavours probably take some getting used to, but I particularly like the fact that Korean spirits are a lot less strong than those usually used in cocktails. And apparently, some of the ingredients have proven health benefits  certainly true for the fresh fruit based ones.We were seated in the beautiful downstairs bar area which has not yet opened to the public, thus missing out on some of the hustle and bustle upstairs. I look forward to coming back and joining one of the mixed tables  even to queueing (average 15 minuts) and making friends with fellow diners along the way.There are obvious similarities to other successful Asian restaurants like Wagamama or BusabaEthai, but Kimchee has a slightly more upmarket feel to it, even though the prices are in a similar range. This is probably due to the great care the owner takes in choosing the crockery and decor for Kimchee. Wherever possible, this is sourced in Korea. We all fell in love with the beautiful Sake glasses (from Japan), and I particularly loved the clay dishes our food was served in  some of the dishes have their own signature plate!As I have never been to Korea before, I can't tell how authentic tonight's experience has been, but with a third of all diners originating from the country, this must be pretty close. The country's Olympic team has already booked their table!We learned a lot about the various foods, and I can't wait to return to sample one of the crispy rice or one-pot mains.I was surprised to find more than one parallel to German food: both love pickled/fermented cabbage (Kimchee is the name of the Korean version of Sauerkraut which is the base of many of the dishes), and steak tartare. The latter is a very brave choice to put on a menu and speaks for the high quality and freshness of the ingredients (in my case judged on appearance alone, I am still too much of a not fully reformed vegetarian).

9NNIBKM4Ocpgx8pQ-uIsCg.text: Ok, I have very mixed feelings with this place because I had a fairly decent experience and the food overall was pretty tasty.  However, lack of authenticity and certain dishes tasting quite off turned me off from giving this place 4 stars.The ambience is very nice.  Clean, well-kept and modern.  The strange part about the restaurant is there are virtually no Koreans in the restaurant.  Now, not to sound weird or anything, but I seriously don't feel comfortable when I go into a restaurant and I am not able to order in my native tongue.  I mean I could see the 2 chefs in the very back were Korean, but that was about it.Starters were decent and same with the side dishes.  The side dishes were decent.  I found the kimchi to be very tasty and not too sour, and not too soft.  It was actually perfect in my opinion.  The sprouts were not very tasty though.  It felt like it was missing sesame oil and of course the sesame seeds as well.  Tsk tsk.The spicy rice cakes were delicious and well made.  I found it to be quite tasty.Entrees.  4 out of the 5 that came out were fairly tasty.  The black bean paste noodles were fairly tasty, but the seafood noodle stew (Jjam Bbong) was a bit on the bland side.  Spice and salt could've been added a bit more and perhaps even using broth instead of water would've worked altogether.  The bbq spicy pork dish was fairly tasty alongside with the bulgogi.  The dish I think that set me off and definitely made me rate this place from a 4 to a 3 was the kimchi cchigae (kimchi stew).  It tasted like miso soup mixed in with the most disgusting ingredients possible.  It was terrible.  My friend liked it because he doesn't know what the dish was supposed to taste like.  I was horrified that this place made this dish this way.  Overall the place isn't too shabby and the service was decent.  The prices were fairly decent considering it was a Korean restaurant and for how much we ordered.  However, I would reconsider going to another restaurant.  The only reason why I came to this one was because it was Sunday night and they served black bean paste noodles.

ySDfkaPJc795tLocJMmkhQ.text: It's a beautiful restaurant with modern decor. Come here for drinks only. Don't stay for the  food. It's not authentic, it's full of sodium & msg, & it's overpriced. I had the seafood tofu dish & been having stomach issues with other unpleasant outcomes. That's unacceptable for a restaurant aspired to be an upscale gourmet establishment.

jHgL15RFAvfEsa4UHHa72w.text: This place is a solid B+ and usually dependable for a quick/no wait situation. The ambiance is also pleasant so I guess that is also a plus. The food is OK but get ready for a lolwut situation if you're expecting something like LA K-town. The pajeon is wilted and lackluster, the kimchee is not complimentary (neither is the rice LOLWUT) and don't even think about banchan. However, the mains are all fine and you can also get tempura if you desire (haha ok suuure).The service is pretty bad so get ready to be heavily involved in flagging down wait staff and to actively campaign to get your water refilled. However, I did see Cha Du-Ri while eating here one time so it can't be all that awful right? RIGHT?

81DdXpp0Lm-OxAi4A3NIwg.text: The food here is very authentic - despite the kitchen looking like Wagamamas! Decor is very stylish and modern, and the prices are reasonable for the area.Definitely gives the Korean place below Holborn station a run for its money.Beware the huge queues though for dinner - they snake out the door! But table turnaround is fast, so you'll be in quickly.They do seem a bit short staffed - takes a bit of time to get your order in and the bill at the end, but once you order, the food arrives quickly.

DwZ94897nbB917Z_GFUV_A.text: I was wildly hungry when I got here which was not ideal as the service is incredibly slow. Also they bring out everything at different times, luckily mine was first so no one got hurt.It's really nice looking restaurant with awesome features like a built in compartment under the seats for keeping your bags - great for people like me who are paranoid about having their stuff snatched!Food was generally quite good I thought, I'd agree with other reviewers that the bibimbap wasn't the best but the bulgalbi was delicious, it's always a favourite of mine. The Kimchee Jeon panckae was quite nice, a good option for vegetarians.I was really disappointed they didn't have the Yuk Hwae (raw beef) because it sounded yum and I wanted to try it. I ended up going for soft shell crab fried in breadcrumbs which wasn't great - just a bit stodgy.For dessert we had the Chap Ssal Ddeok which is a weird spongy rice cake. It was DELICIOUS. Like eating a really delicious slug.If you haven't tried Korean before and want somewhere easy to get to this (or Tohbang which isn't far) is a good enough place to start. Otherwise, head to New Malden!

n2ug-Gg07ZKvgPM5XkgzhA.text: This is by FAR the B.E.S.T Korean food in London. Every time I visit London and am craving Korean food, this is the go-to place. They recently did a huge renovation and added a bar in the basement. Keep in mind that they had an office and just bathrooms downstairs. Sometimes there is a long line at Kimchee because this is the poppin spot! The renovation was overall a great idea because people can now hang out and lounge downstairs at the bar while they wait. Since London is known for its bipolar weather, people won't have to wait in the rain ( ;Customers can also meet new people at the bar, which is a plus for everybody. As for the food, it is deeelicious.I always order the "Seafood Dol Sot Bibimbap", which is one of their unique dishes at Kimchee. It consists of all different kinds of seafoods and the best part is the nooroongji a.k.a (rice that turns a little hard like a chip that you eat at the end). Another dish that I order when I go here is the Galbi without the bones. The meat is soft and the Korean touch to it is made to perfection. Drooling as I am thinking of this dish at the moment. I also recommend Makgeolli. This is a drink made from rice and is my personal favorite. It is kind of like rice wine and tastes amazing. If you like carbonated drinks, add sprite to Makgeolli and it is bombtastic! But be careful not to drink too much because this will get you a crazy hangover just like wine. If you live in London and want to try authentic Korean food, this is the place to go! Trust me, I'm Korean ( :

YhgkZsZMRNGQYZzTLz0K1A.text: Very modern decor, but thats no suprise as the full length windows give you a peek into what to expect. I arrived with a Korean friend who I knew would introduce me to traditional dishes. We were seated at the window, where I felt we were on display to pedestrian walking by, prefer to sit away next time just felt like I had to be on best behaviour lol.Food was good quality and fortunately my friend tells me the kimchi was quite good very crispy not too limp.When the bill arrived it was a pleasant surprise to see the total - very reasonable indeed.Was looking forward to coming here for a while, im not sure if I'll be coming back in a hurry but wouldn't rule it out if I were in the area looking for dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom

ujRIqSBT-6Bk4NUTeQXHlA.text: To start with, their Kimchi is probably the best I ever had. Jap Chae was also very nice and the size was proportionate to its price (4.90 means a small plate). HOWEVER, their beef bibimbap was a huge disappointment. The rice was incredibly overcooked and the overall dish lacked taste. Maybe I should give it another try, however, in other Korean restaurants I fell in love with bibimbap on the first try. Otherwise--The prices were surprisingly low, service very nice.

Cp1oBQy8y2V8LnH_lxrj9w.text: I went there a few weeks ago with a friend. I wanted to try it for a long time since a Korean friend recommended it. Before we walked inside I thought it was gonna be quite expensive. Because the environment of the restaurant was very nicely done and they definitely spent a lot on the decor. It was quite packed even though it was in the middle of the week. The receptionist got us a table in no time, but we had to share with another 2 ladies. The food and price were not bad at all, it wasn't expensive. It would be nice if one wants to eat decent Korean food in a nice environment without spending fortune (well, you can spend a fortune if you like, of course depends on how and what you order...). The down side of this restaurant was, the catchphrase of the waiters were "Wait a minute, I'll be back!" But then, 5 mins, 10 mins, 15 mins, no one was back... It was a bit annoying... And it would be better if going as a group of 4 at least to occupy the whole table, otherwise one would have to share the benches, which was very difficult to get into when someone else was already there, and had to sit very closely to each other...

GXQdcRTB7OZMwkujiv927g.text: Good concept, great ambience, unfortunately, subpar korean food. The beef noodles were tasteless and not at all Korean- soup was bland and barely spicy. Japchae was tasteless. The only thing that tasted good was the milky morning sunshine tea (or whatever it's called)Won't spend 10pounds here again, sorry

2MklZbhK-HYjPYJGI9HonA.text: I am in no position to say if the food is authentic, but it made the impression. I can tell you it tasted great and I cannot wait to get back there again. You get, as is usual, lots of batches of small meals that you eat together. Do not go there alone. Your meal is filled with many different taste and I really enjoyed exploring all the dishes that we ordered rather without knowing what we did. But the waitress was very friendly and exceptionally helpful. Yes, we have been seated after a only five minute wait, walking past a good two dozen other people waiting. But then again, we have only been a party of two. I could imagine it takes some time to seat 5 at a crowded evening

EWkPV8DwwPzohxGIreEwBA.text: Kimchee serves tasty Korean food at the heart of Bloomsbury in a modern restaurant. I cannot comment on the 'authenticity' of the cuisine as this was my first Korean meal, however I can comment on the taste and it was delicious.Beautifully presented, everything was very well cooked and flavours were pure and noticeable. Service was very nice and caring, and they were short on staff so they had half the tables closed - a good decision as they prioritised good service over filling the room.Desserts were delicious and cocoa rice cakes particularly recommended... next time I will have a box of those to go!At £18 per person excluding drinks it is quite a good deal for the area and quality.

KYQDCG0su8BCQ9baChHNKA.text: I am the first to admit that whilst I love Asian food, I know very little about it. I feel extremely privileged therefore to have been invited to the VIQ event at Kimchee for a crash course in Korean food. This restaurant is one of a kind, currently an ambassador, that has not yet made it to chain-hood. I cannot emphasise the passion that the staff of Kimchee have for this variety of cuisine, their attention to detail, their desire to make this cuisine accessible for all, and just how much they know about their menu. I came away with a greater appreciation of the smells and tastes from this region and whilst I can understand that for many this may be an acquired taste, I personally developed a thirst for more. Being one of very few Korean restaurants in London, this restaurant, which is close to Holborn tube (so accessible from the centre), concentrates solely on this cuisine. They even go so far as (those who are sensitive to their carbon footprint skip to the next paragraph) sourcing the majority of their ingredients and table ware from Korea to ensure as authentic a taste and experience as possible. With a third of its guests claiming to be Korean, you cannot but help feel they have achieved their goal. This restaurant had actually been recommended to me previously, but upon arriving I found a queue formed outside so went for another option. I regret not having listened to this recommendation. Known for it's queues, this restaurant does not offer a reservation service (although this was mentioned as something they will be looking into for larger parties). The ethos being to make this restaurant accessible to everyone, and not just those that book in advance. Although it was mentioned that the Korean Olympic team has secured a spot. First impressions were extremely positive, low hung geometric lights create a warm ambient atmosphere and the high grade décor provide a feeling of elegance and sophistication. I was extremely impressed with the water feature and Zen like rock garden waiting area at the entrance, it created a peaceful place to wait whilst our tables were being prepared. This restaurant offers a communal dining experience, so you will be seated where they can fit you in (Wagamama style) although there are looking to open a new area for larger groups downstairs. Being a communal restaurant you are also encouraged to share smaller plates, however the menu features larger mains with the expectation that you will order a main and share a few smaller dishes. So that brings me on to the most stimulating part of the Kimchee experience, the amazing food and drink selection. On our visit we were greeted by a table furnished with high grade dinning ware which gave the dishes we sampled an air of culinary chic. Throughout the evening we were provided with a selection of smaller dishes including: Yang Yeum Chicken, spicy pieces of bread crumbed chickenYuk Hwae, a Asian version of what in the west we would call steak tartare. High grade steak with sesame seeds, pear and cucumber and a raw egg yolkCrab Tuigim, crispy fried soft shell crabGogi mandu, which are like dumplings or GyozaPa Jeon, a type of omelette pancake with seafoodKimchee, which, if you are astute you'll realise is the name of the restaurant, which is a dish of cabbage, layered with spices and left to ferment I would have to say that it is hard to pick a favourite from these as each was delightful, each garnished with fresh herbs, where crisp, never oily and each presented perfectly. However, a highlight of the experience was trying Kimchee, something which I have never heard of before. This is slightly fizzy on the tongue and reminded me of globki, a polish dish, with cabbage and spicy mince, however obviously without the meat. Apparently this dish, used as an ingredient in much of the menu, contains elements that aid digestion and the fair skin of older Korean women has been attributed to its unique properties. I didn't notice a change in my complexion, but as this was delightful, I wouldn't mind eating this on a more regular basis, regardless. I also enjoyed the Yuk Hwae, which I was assured is the most popular dish of the western visitors to this restaurant. The meat was succulent and the taste sophisticated and which would be very appealing to a number of my red blooded friends. The drinks included (if that is I recall them correctly), Mae Wha Soo, a sweet plum wine, Makgeolli a rice based fermented drink that smelt like Banana's and had somewhat of a taste of unripe banana, and Soju, which is a clear vodka like spirit that is weaker in strength and sweeter in taste. We also sampled a number of cocktails, which were lovely, but rather sweet for my tastes. My highlight would be the plum wine, which I have tried previously and remains a firm favourite. Having persuaded the menu, I was also pleasantly surprised by the price, it is very reasonable, especially when you take into account the quality of the food and surroundings. I had a

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom

L_5Qz0pAXq4wHwap0nXBpA.text: Gorgeous, gorgeous place.  It is impressive.  But we're not here to look at decor are we?  For the price of the dishes, it isn't bad.  I was definitely a little skeptical walking in and seeing the open kitchen with the lack of korean cooks in there.  The kimchee (cabbage & raddish) were both NOT pickled!  Seasoning was good but need to let it sit for a bit.  I wasn't very happy with the service.  We ordered the regular Pajeon and they gave us the kimchee one... I sent it back and our waitress came up and said here it is - you ordered this.  I said no we didn't - then she asked us if we can just take it because it's already made.  Um, no.  We ended up getting what we ordered which came out pretty good.  Spicy prawns - okay.  I actually really enjoyed my dish Budae jigae. Red soju cocktail - ick!  Sorry it's a bit like cough medicine.  I must've switched my rating between 2 and 3 stars a couple of times but after thinking about the service - had to settle with the 2.  However I am willing to give this place one more try...

1J3lBkltY8Fkfgqihu6gYQ.text: Absolutely love this place! Had walked past many times reminding myself to visit one day and I'm so glad I did. The decor is unique and modern and the staff are friendly. They were very willing to explain the menu to us.We visited purely based on the appearance outside and the menu. The food is delicious, very tasty. I had the seafood bibimbap which filled me up, I didn't want it to end! To drink I had the kimberry cocktail which I finished pretty quick it was too good! Being on the main road between Holborn and Chancery Lane station, it was very easy to find. Can't wait to visit here again!

GsrZ1P2JxwWzhUbkMmKW2A.text: During the young'un days of Minnie M, there wasn't a week that went by when evenings ended in KTown and 3 am feasts of galbi and jigae.  Alas, that was before the London years of yours truly.Now, the best alternative is going into Kimchee at 5:30 pm to skip the long waits and queues and eating FOREVER ALONE.  But it's okay, I was finally able to satisfy my Korean food cravings.I like the decor and the open space, but its food is only okay.  I ordered the tofu salad, which was really salty.  Think they may have doused the soba in a lot of soy sauce.  But that's cool, I was only there for the tofu and seafood jigae... which was also a bit disappointing.  They put a lot of chilli oil in it, and if you're well versed with the comfort of jigae during a wintry day, you know it's the flavors of the stew that should be the highlight, not the oil swimming on top.  Also, 2 quid for rice?  Outrageous.Roasted green tea ice cream was good though.  I love me some green tea ice  cream.It's a restaurant worth checking on during non peak times, but if you're looking for authentic Korean go to New Malden.

rDiJnrFggZY8vXFpsjhvAg.text: Food was subpar tasted pre prepared service and atmosphere was nice however there are better options in the area

3fVIf8mmELVEwQAso9rIcA.text: Pretty posh!I still prefer the homier Tohbang but Kimchee has a few offerings that my Korean standby on Clerkenwell Road does not, namely:frozen yogurt jjajangmyeonSince I really, really love both, and being in nicely designed spaces, I'll be back. Especially if I'm on my own as the long bar in the window seems perfect for a spot of solo dining.

3W6cd5pW35VkJLYzdNpAmA.text: Good food. Good music. Desserts are mediocre and unimaginative. Expensive. I only went here for a birthday party.

CPOuBZDV11weEqvXap0jjw.text: The problem with Kimchee is that they are never overly pleased to see you. You always get the impression that customers are a bit of a chore, and that one should feel honoured to be allowed to be there at all.The food really isn't good enough to justify that kind of attitude. So it's low on my list of choices. The menu is pretty limited with only 3-4 options for veggies most of which involve tofu. To go with the poor attitude and average food is bad and highly variable service.The decor is ok, the acoustics terrible. You get crammed in canteen style.

I3vPMtrCeLKvruE3dqCQKA.text: your table" experience (which I love doing!), but the plus side is, you won't walk away smelling like BBQ and garlic and you can enjoy your meal without having to check to see if your BBQ is done or not. If it's your first time eating Korean, make sure you go with someone who know how to eat Korean BBQ (yes, there is a specific way), or order something from this list and you can't go wrong (unless you're allergic):1. scallions and seafood pancakes (pa-jeon) 2. Kimchee pancakes (kimchee-jeon) 3. fried tofu with kimchee and pork (doo boo kimchee) 4. spicy rice cakes (ttuk bok gi) 5. soft tofu stew/soup (soon doo boo jji gae) 6. Korean BBQ beef (galbi) 7. Korean spicy pork BBQ (pork galbi) 8. beef stone pot rice (dol sot bibimbap) 9. glass noodles (jap chae). The icecreams are really good, too! (red bean, green tea, chestnut, black sesame and almond).

zeUevBQFkTcpjN9dA99Bnw.text: Quick review:+ authentic Korean taste+ nice decor- small portionsFull review:Kimchee is centrally located (well, close enough to my work place anyway) for satisfying my cravings for Korean food, with dishes like raw beef bibimbap. The portion size is pretty small for the price, but the setting is chic and staff are friendly enough. The food comes quickly and in batches - whenever they are cooked, they are delivered.

bJ87SIbH_952l-J97d6VpA.text: Kimchee, you are at the bottom of my list for many reasons.1. The host taking names at the door is rather incompetent and seats other parties before yours. You must remind her/him that you have been waiting longer and only then will you be next in line to be seated.2. Your service stinks. Placing any order requires serious arm flailing to catch the attention of your too few staff. Paying the bill takes a good fifteen minutes. It is only when you physically get up, put on your coats, and start walking to the door does your server bring the bill. 3. The food is passable Korean but not authentic. The servers can not properly pronounce the food names and corrects you when you say them correctly.4. You are seated at communal tables (which I have greatly enjoyed elsewhere) that are overpacked. Even the servers must turn to the side and suck it in to clear the walkways. Why would I go back when I can go to Naru or Tohbang, both a 10 minute walk from Kimchee?

eFtO9GgFsSUYRFcX80xctw.text: Good food! Price makes sense. The furnishings are trendy and delicate. Seems like a good place for hanging outs and dates.

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Food is good! Price makes sense. Pretty trendy furnishings inside. I would definitely recommend it!

fHnVvW6dZXRZhrXSZf7gUQ.text: Had the chargrilled spicy pork. Was so nice. Was running late but would have been better to order more as the portion size was not as big. Great service.

GO5N77wj7OV_2FTCtX9bZg.text: This is officially the first time I visited an exclusive Korean restaurant (although I've eaten Korean food many times before).First I begin to tell of how trendy and hip the place looked. It is located in the centre of the city and very approachable by subway. The restaurant had a very spacious place, very well decorated, modern and well-designed furniture, and above all, frequented by young and well-dressed people.The service was quite below average, IMO. The  waitress seemed to forget a lot and we have to wait a considerable time before they noticed us and ask to make the order.The food was delicious though. The kimchee was quite tasty and the dolsot bibimbap was delicious and fulfilling. But the best food we tried on this restaurant were the desserts. Although they were not "traditionally" Korean, it was something I've never tasted before. I highly recommend the green tea jelly with Matang.

Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Chestnut ice cream
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Green tea jelly with Matang

c9E4nJUe7BkuCBy--K-ZCQ.text: I've been saving my 100th review for some place special. This is my new restaurant crush- so it has to be here!I've been to their fast food little sister Kimchee-To-Go a billion times and thought it was finally time to try the official restaurant. I suggested it for a family get together and we were all made believers. I quickly decided to have my birthday dinner here.Pluses: +The decor is modern and chic with a feel of Asian screens and Korean ceramics on display which is right next to:+The open kitchen. I have to restrain myself not to shove a fancy lettuce leaf in my mouth as I walk by.+Good for groups with long tables+FOOD FOOD FOODA huge selection for all sorts of eaters. The vegan selection is pretty impressive. Buckwheat noodle salad, vegetable dumplings, soups, bibimbap, and my current fav: Stir fried Udon. (I tend to not get stir fried udon because I could easily make it at home. After trying someone else's, I promptly made sure I had a whole portion to myself the next time. And I did.) Meat & seafood dishes were also given a thumbs up by the crowd.+Vegetarian dishes are clearly marked.+Cocktails. Quite an array of interesting-in-a-good-way drinks including traditional (dairy free) rice milk alcohol. I love the Kimberry (raspberry liqueur, rice milk brew, raspberries and mint).+Prices. Pretty decent! Mains are under £9.+Toilets! I go as many times as possible because they are that nice. I also like to admire the waiting-area lounge downstairs.Minuses:-No reservations. Make sure most of your group comes together (silver lining: you can wait at the cool bar downstairs for a table)-Group tables can only fit 8 people, separating a larger group a bit. I'm not sure if the tables can be pushed together (especially if it's busy).-No vegetarian kimchi (but they do have namuls)-I want/attempt to eat everything.Bonus points:Friends are super impressed and thus impressed with you.See you soon, Kimchee!

YhilSYB6xr1uxsWAOqOf9A.text: Found a delightfully modern yet classic tasting Korean restaurant in London. From the decor to the mocktails,  to the food, 4 stars!  I was in the mood for Bibimbop and Patbingsu. The kimchee was perfect.  It was all so perfectly yummy. !!

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. I was in the mood for Bibimbop and Patbingsu. The kimchee was perfect.  It was all so perfectly yummy. !!

XQSP_bl5Xw_oHtpBEfXTKQ.text: Oh my - a restaurant in central London that is beautifully designed, has fantastic food and reasonable prices! I will definitely be coming back here. And they have a good music playing in the background!

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Dumplings and Pancake
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Raw beef bimbimbap

exAbwVlILjnlwe2vFFIfEA.text: I came here right after I arrived in London in February because my friends have been wanting to try it. It was super crowded and we waited for about 10 minutes for our party of three. I ordered the jajangmyeon and a pot of green tea. I would say the portion was average, maybe a bit too small for me but I eat a lot. We also shared some bulgogi which came with lettuce and that was also pretty good. Not the best Korean food I've had, but it wasn't bad either!

BUHlIp7FPSiqbudszShNng.text: 3 stars because the food is delicious but the service is horrible. Took forever to get our server to come to our table and for our food to come as well. Very disappointed

KamumQlGbTmOt_4wlwnvvg.text: Not bad but not the best. On arrival I couldn't be seated as my friend was 5 minutes away. Fair enough when there is a queue and no seats but the place was pretty sparse. Once she arrived the waiters ignored us for a few minutes before seating us but barely speaking to us. We went for the beef bibimbap and chicken udon noodles. Luckily we were sharing both as the bibimbap came out straight away and the chicken noodles 10 minutes later. The bibimbap was average - beef ok but sauce not all that flavoursome and the veg in there wasn't as good as other places I have tried. I would not recommend this. However the fried chicken udons was DELICIOUS. Lovely thick noodles in a peanut sauce which onions, peppers and fried breadcrumbed chicken. Recommend this. I will be back to try another few things on the menu as the food was reasonably priced and the restaurant it big, spacious with a nice decor. Shame about service and the bibimbap.

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom

oS25H0_sCVd1bv9OvXmUnQ.text: Oh Kimchee what a shame! You *could* be so good!!I'll go with the good parts first, as some things really made me happy here:* As everyone else has mentioned, Kimchee looks chic, and cool. The toilets were be-autiful with nice smelling soap.  * It has mouth-watering meat broiling next to a glass window at the front to get your appetite up. Yum.* The food is pretty good. It seems like an Alan Yau-type of establishment (like Busaba, Wagamama, Cha cha moon etc.) so it's not too pricey, but well presented, decent grub. If the service was better, it'd be a solid 3 or 4 stars.But this is all let down by the service!* We had to wait in the line outside for about 20 minutes, then another 15 minutes inside. This isn't such a biggie...I'm getting used to it in London now BUT as they had given us the menu while we waited, we were all ready to order by the time we sat down. However the waitress wandered off never to be seen again! It took at least 10 minutes before we could flag someone down to let us order! - Eep 1.* The staff didn't really know how much we should order for starters. We were planning to share several things, but our waiter didn't know if they'd be easy to split...he didn't really know anything when we questioned him about our order. It made us wonder if he'd ever actually eaten the food here - Eep 2.* They took an incredibly long time to bring drinks. When they finally arrived, they brought me the wrong wine, and took even longer to bring my friend's beer. We had to ask twice before the beer arrived. Eep 3.* We asked for tap water when we ordered when we first sat down. They didn't bring it until we had almost finished. Eep 4. * They didn't bring plates, so it was hard to share the starters. Wtf - Eep 5.* They didn't bring spoons for the soup(!) I really don't know how they expected me to eat soup from a hot pot with chopsticks! Eep 6.* They added an extra service charge to our bill despite their terrible service. Oh! And then the waiter took a really long time to bring back our change...maybe he was hoping we'd just leave without it so he'd gain an extra tip!? Ah well.

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. time to practice reading Hangul :)
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Meaty view while you wait for a table...

pRMrbHtLGwyyJpHFbHKWnA.text: My first legitimate Korean food experience in London!  I was so excited.  The restaurant, upon walking in, felt very modern and impressive.  With high ceilings and spacious interiors, I thought this was no ordinary K-Town type of Korean restaurant.  However, as the meal progressed, I realized that the noise level was a bit too much.  Perhaps, for any serious get-togethers, you should ask for a private room.The food, overall, was average.  Of what we ordered, my favorite was the tofu & kimchee.  The ribeye felt a bit too chewy for me, though I found its barbecue/wasabi sauce creative. Galbi woogujee stew was solid.  Initially, we ordered yukhui as well (raw meat sushi), but it came out way too salty, so we ended up canceling it.  Finally, there was no side dishes usually served at Korean restaurants which I felt was a bit of a cheat.All in all, a safe choice to go for a sit-in Korean food, but I do feel like there could be better ones out there in London.

0L9D1ALOUPyVKWHh5h1sHw.text: As a big fan of Korean food from the US, I am indeed quite surprised that London does not offer a big variety of Korean cuisines. When I went to kimchee for the first time I had seafood pancake and bibimbap. It was alright, not great. It does not feel authentic. Feels much more commercialized and manufactured. The second time was much more disappointing when I found out a simple kimchee soup would cost £9 with £2 extra if served with rice. Is this a joke?! Having lived in the States for many years, korean bbq and soups have been my favorite because of the high quality and affordable price ~ $10 for a big meal. It is very upsetting to pay a lot of money for not so great food just because of the convenient location and stylish design.

QqcNUYqGJiwGiR0ly6eXYg.text: Really enjoyed it...especially decor-wise I was very impressed. Think Hakkasan and a more refined Ping Pong (Great Marlborough Street) and you kind of know what to expect.But also food-wise the restaurant ticked my boxes: the presentation was beautiful and the flavours were spot-on. Especially the barbecued beef was a tasty revelation (despite the texture being a little too chewy). Another standout is the staffing: my dining companion remarked that she felt like in an international hostel where people from all over the world worked: you were led to the table by Miss Poland, served drinks by Mr Korea; your orders were taken by Mme French and the bill was presented by Mr Turkish...While I really enjoyed this international flair, I think - like in the real world - they have not really learned how to play well together, nor are they aces when it comes to hospitality. After all, just because you have a fancy ear-piece and a walky-talky doesn't mean you're very well-organised!Yet, like I said in the beginning, I was really quite impressed and can definitely recommend you to pay a visit to this establishment! Jal Meokkesseumnida (which, according to Google, means Bon Appetit in Korean.)

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom

9iBOOFAnT2HZ9J2C2D5sYg.text: You know a korean restaurant is good when they bang out the kim chi ji gae. Absolutely amazing! Must try when in London and you are craving Korean food. A bit pricy but well worth every dollar.

nR0YA0idtkEjRGprrbk46w.text: The food was decent however I've never felt more rushed after a meal in my life! The guy grabbed my card from my hand and paid contactless without telling me what the price was! When I said he should never do that again with MY CARD he looked at me like I stole his card! You need some serious customer service... I mean.. your food is only decent so wouldn't rely on that too much

QHgLu7YaMW-SZlO1T3s-Pg.text: Fake Korean food and it's not even good. The server for our table was nice, except that he spilled the soup on my shirt. I was expecting a discount, but all I got was an apology and my ruined shirt. I think this place is meant for people with low standards for their appetites.

RrzcmtybOD2n3PUFxYn-dQ.text: What a great place to get some yummy Korean lunch. This shop operates along the same line as Wasabi and Itsu. Salads, sushi and noodles are packed up neatly, to be either eaten in or taken back to the work place.We had the Korean pancake, hot tofu salad and a mix of sushi and noodles plus plum tea and Aloe Vera for drinks. It decently priced and the portions were very nice. Loads of vegetarian options.

Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom

PYDbAe7PyzPgWg3Wv7T_ag.text: I was studying a little ways down at Starbucks with a friend and we decided to find some lunch. Although the reviews from Kimchee on Yelp are pitiful, I figured I'd head in and come to my own conclusion...If you're looking for traditional Korean food, go somewhere is. If you're looking for Korean-inspired food, come here. It's not bad at all, but I felt some of the flavors were a bit off. We ordered the Beef bibimbap along with an order of bulgalbi. The bibimbap was pretty good, but I was a bit disappointed with the bulgalbi. It just lacked flavor... & the best thing about ordered galbi in a traditional Korean setting is the marinated flavor on it. My happy ending to this lunch was the black sesame ice cream. It is amazing!Great atmosphere here and a decent lunch spot. I'd honestly come back to try a few more things on the menu. Service wasn't particularly bad or good, but the food comes out rather quickly so that's always a good thing.
