6BJaGrfjY5mvNQ85FM02RA.text: Solid fast casual Korean in the heart of Holborn - I wont be ringing any phones for the food here but its solid and hits the spot if you want a quick Korean fix. Of notable repute is the kimchee pancake (so thick and crunchy and delicious) and the black sesame panna cotta (came with a cherry apple which provided our table with endless amusement)

p8hcZDQgpgObONsdoihcpw.text: I have been on a number of occasions now. Love the decor and the really large space inside. Each time I have been with friends they are impress with the restaurant and the fact it doesn't require reservation, that's a thumbs up. However it can mean super long waiting times. Tried most dishes, everything was good, however there were some noodle dishes which were a let down. I also generally like it extra spicy in my pork dishes, but wasn't so. Their main dishes were great though, packed with flavour, served up well with nice fluffly rice. Yum. The service is a hit and miss. Can be really attentive and then very hard to get a hold of. I love Korean food and the small authentic restaurants whether they are in new Malden or central London are really great, cozy and homey food with a Korean romance drama feel all the time. Kimchee gives a more fancy family friendly vibe, and not so tense atmosphere which sometimes I prefer.

pdHEFbLfy7mad2iLFKMM-g.text: This was one of the BEST restaurants I had during my time in London. The food is reasonably priced and the atmosphere of the place was astounding.During a Thursday night, the wait was a bit long (30 minutes but still), but the staff were incredibly friendly. DEFINITELY stop by this place if you have the chance!

_j-tN_DbbBFMB23JIwjvJg.text: I was staying at the hotel nearby and was walking around on Sunday looking for some good food. I chanced about Kimchee and decided to see what Korean London was about. It turned out to be quite good actually.The beef bibimbap was very good. The beef is raw and cooks in the pot. It was tasty but I wanted more protein and I got the bulgogi beef as well which was good too. The decor was very trendy, nice use of wood and water and they have a nice bar downstairs.Service was not great and hence the 3 star review... I had to ask for a help anytime I needed something, they never checked up on me.

9KKl8pl_VuJCPKWA7PY6Og.text: Modern restaurant with OK Korean food- one thing the U.K. doesn't really have is a real K-Town, although I'm told the place to go is New Malden on the fringes of London. There are a few places in central London, including this one , which feels like it's competing with the likes of Wasabi and Itsu. However, I'd say the food, while not perfect, is infinitely preferable to the vat cooking at the former, and the general insipidity of the latter. Expect to pay about £9 for a drink, a side ( ie kimchee), and a main ( the Korean fried chicken is nice, but not stellar) to eat in.

Sk6NnR93xH8NbREjm_xlEQ.text: Well, well.. what do we have here.  I must say, I'm quite amazed.. I give this restaurant a 3star. SO,so... Three star for Effort... I'm totally impressed.  There's so many things you can say about European food.  They should stick to what they do best which is probably baking? Good breads,  pastries.. Food... hmmmph... I haven't tried French cuisine yet.. so I can't say much about that.. but Asian in Europe, they should just give it up.  But this place,  the Ambiance. Wow,  totally killed it! Check out the photos! The serve ware.. I think that's what I came here for.  Lol. And,  I must say,  London, everything is overpriced.. but This restaurant was decently priced.. so I totally commend them.  What took away the 2 stars was the flavor and the traditional Korean.  So.. the staffs were really nice.. they seated us like a fast food way.. by the window.. lol. They were full.. anyway,  we ordered King prawns for appetizer,  spicy beef soup for my hubby and I asked the server if the beef rib eye was part of the bulgogi or not..and she said yes.. but a different type of meat that's why it is more expensive.  So, I chose the rib eye.  But when I got the order, the beef tasted so bland, like it did not have any flavor.. and remember,  bulgogi is a marinated meat.  So ...I asked her again.. and that's when she found out it was a totally different dish.  So they had to changed it.  I told my hubby,  you know,  a restaurant cannot just throw in a dish that's made of a wholesome insipid meat.  I can do that at home.  You go to a restaurant because you want something divergent.  That meat was not any different.  That should not even be in the menu.  But they were nice enough to change it with no questions asked.  We were stuffed.  Totally worth the price, after I had my real bulgogi. You just expect side dishes when you go to a Korean restaurant.. that's where they lost the Korean tradition,  hence the other star.  You have to pay for the side dishes.  Lol. Understandable.  Lol. Everything here in London is an extra euro. But again,  so far,  this is the most reasonable and palatable restaurant I've been to.  And modern fusion at that! Love it! For London... 3 star is pretty good coming from me! By the way the soju, I thought $5 in the US was allay expensive, hold you breath for the 9euros here! That's like $15us! Lol. 3x the price! Lol. Omg! Highway robbery!

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Beef rib eye steak
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Spicy beef stew
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. King prawns appetizer

-ZwwNtSDOce20K7UNL89ig.text: Somewhere between 3.5-4 stars. It's a beautiful restaurant interior with very attentive staff eager to please. They have a lovely menu with a wide variety of Korean specialities and everything was beautifully presented. The scallop appetizer was delicious, although tiny. Kalbi set with rice and lettuce wraps was also very good, but the quality of the meat could have been better. I really enjoyed their kimchi as well. I would definitely come back to try more flavors.

X5qvmQaf_AQkJQHrGRCc8Q.text: Since this was a higher-end establishment, my expectations were high.  Being from California, I am privileged to frequent a variety of Korean restaurants, so I know what I am looking for with Korean food.  I feared that Korean food in London would not meet my standards, and I was glad my fears were unfounded.  I came with a large party of ~20 guests, and got to sample many dishes.  I am glad to report this place serves good, authentic Korean dishes.  I was especially impressed by my dessert dish, Korean pear poached in rock sugar.  This is a medicinal dish that is rare to find in restaurant menus, even in California.The only thing not authentic about the whole experience was the music.  Granted I was only there for one evening, but all of the songs they played were covers!  I think these are the same cover songs one would find in karaoke clubs, when they don't have the copyright to play songs by original artists.

0HOAAX_1llvhjTn3MJy2gg.text: A fancy-looking Korean restaurant but it feels too overpriced compared to the amount of the food actually given. I guess you could say what Asian restaurant isn't overpriced? Well I had the non-bulgogi pork menu and literally just grilled pork served with lettuce and sauces. What part of this menu was supposed to be Korean? The sauce? Okay I should have ordered something else to make it feel more 'Korean' but hope that they add some side-dishes or others so that it's not just some menus that have the Korean spice in it. Well I guess you could go here with friends to try a variety of Korean food (by going with the family style eating).

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. The non-bulgogi pork menu (forgot the name). It's just meat, two sauces, and lettuce.

GSS6e8OXzfRbhN65mLs35g.text: Overall food was pretty good and came out relatively fast but the service was kind of slow and the servers didn't really talk to us much. Got the budae jjigae, galbi, and hot pot bulgogi. The bulgogi was really good, kind of a sweet flavor. The budae jjigae was a bit too spicy for my taste even though I asked them to make it less spicy. The meat in it was a bit on the overcooked side but overall the broth was pretty good.

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. budae jjigae

aE5xfinP32mEe1ZWTadakA.text: A couple of friends and I went to Kimchee after work.  The decor is stylish and contemporary with floor to ceiling windows.  It was empty when we arrived (around 6pm), but it filled up very quickly.We ordered the seafood pancake, dduk bok gi and the tofu kimchi to share.  I thought they were all very good but I would have to say the tofu kimchi was my favorite.  The tofu pieces were perfectly fried and the kimchi was just salty enough.I had the beef dolsot bibimbap which was very good (and hot).  My only complaint is that they were slightly stingy on the beef, otherwise it was as perfect bibimbap!I would definitely recommend Kimchee if you're in the area.  The service was quick, the food was good, and the atmosphere was lively!

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Tofu kimchi
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Dduk bok gi
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Beef bibimbap

7S-LWgL775kaMgQoEeKeyw.text: Pretty good value for money and a solid range of Korean tastiness.  We came for dinner but I reckon I'll be back for a few lunches.  Good nudge on the side order of kimchi in itself!

tYowO22ZvGFFcpz8_UNYpg.text: The host was ridiculous, ignoring us for over 15 minutes while there are plenty of available seats and no other people waiting. When I went to speak to him to get his attention, he was super rude and showed zero interest in customer service. Even though food is amicable, service is below the lowest acceptable standard, so had to leave

RZia-y1gcnY8Bac3KN6AEw.text: I've never had Korean food before but it was top noch and I loved it. Deciding what to have was my biggest dilemma with so much nice food. There were two of us and we ordered just enough. For starter it was the dumplings and onion pancake. Which wasn't at all spicy which is what it says on the menu. For main I went for the salmon gui and was pleasantly surprised when it came out. The sweet potato basket wasn't quite what I expected. The sweet potato had been shredded into some type of crunchy nest but it complimented the salmon well. I order rice as well but didn't really need it as we ordered jap chae as a side which was fine. Found room to try a dessert too and went for the golden chestnut ice cream. Tasty but was kind of a glamourised vanilla. All in all a good experience and very busy restaurant which says it all.

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Dumplings!!
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Salmon gui
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Jap chae - marinated beef

5ta85-mxIODmLAEXRYmO8w.text: This is not the authentic Korean experience. They have Korean flavors but that's about it. The restaurant should be "inspired by Korea," but not to be considered Korean. I was broken hearted because I took my British friends here to show them a new cultural experience since I couldn't transport them back home to LA. The soju isn't authentic either, it's too sweet (the pear) and barely tolerable. Luckily, my friends were happy but I was not. I felt like a terrible hostess. The pro's: its walkable from the British Museum. They have a gluten free menu. The cons: all of the above.

ayCYJGFHnBIEPvky7YvP1w.text: Two and a half stars..Very pricy westernized korean food. Everything is super sweet. My beef hotpot was sweet to the point where i didn't want to eat it. My friends ordered beef and the portions were extremely small. Wouldn't come back

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Beef hotpot

lmHKDGQa0nXK43pyJWMLwg.text: Place was busy, so the service was not great.  Banchan, rice, and seaweed (kim) were extra, so my wife only got the rice, as I refuse to pay extra for what is standard when eating out for Korean (banchan and rice is included in Korean restaurants in South Korea and most places in the United States).  Although my wife can't bear to be without Korean food for more than 1-2 days, I can wait a bit longer.Got the tteokbokki, doenjang-jjigae, and jjampong.  Nice and spicy jjampong and Tteokbokki, but my wife was not satisfied with the doenjang-jjigae.  I noticed that her portion was rather small.  Came here on a recommendation from a Korean living in London.  Not sure why, she recommended the place.  Although it was busy, the food was not as good as I was anticipating based on prior reviews.  Also expensive for what you get.

lRpdB2qJpEBwAjzdKBHlCg.text: 1. Food, awesome. Had the Rib Eye, 3x Yuk Hwae (awesome!!!) and the seafood pancakes. Great cocktails too, very interesting mixes with green tea, coconut water and rhum! 2. Great service, super quick. We had to wait maximum 5 minutes for a table (it was full) and the bar area is nice!3. Thank you Pinky (our waitress) and sorry if I surprised you with the 3 Yuk Hwae...

Rjvesm27Ae8f6k2u_JxP9A.text: The food was great, but the service was terrible. The waitress forgot my food, then when I asked about my bimibap it she brought out a side of rice. I then told her this isn't what I ordered. She then remembered, and said it would be 2 minutes because my party finished eating. When I asked her to cancel it, she again said it would take 2 mins. So my food came out when everyone else was finished. It also took forever to get our check, and I finally asked another waiter to help us. Aaaaand that side of rice I didn't order was on the check. They seemed annoyed that I asked them to remove it. They also made it seem like splitting the check was a big deal... Which I'll let go because he's not the first server who flipped out when I asked for a check split in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Dolsot bibimbap with tofu.

pCGzGk9P26t3qs8dNYf2hA.text: Not delicious. Just tolerable. Service sucks. Waited like 15 min for ordering and another 10 min for checking. And it's expensive. Not a place for quick lunch. Disappointing.

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Just tolerable.

KdHFlR4bSACuvfT1da_fbg.text: Delicious choice of Korean dishes! Quickly served and on your table. Affordable prices so makes best for couples or groups!

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Quick to accommodate 8 people. Drinks and food service came out within 10-15 mins. Seafood jiigae just hit the spot!

1GV4IPWqS_kGTEnrPGVeSA.text: A nice ambiance cozy restaurant. They have nice selection of tea which complement well with their food. Recommended to try their Tea!The bebimbap taste just like the one I have in Korea. Cheese tokpokki is so cheesy!  Seafood Jam pong is not spicy but it is great. I would come back if feeling Korean in London again. And most importantly, the staff are great!

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Marinated chicken bebimbap
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Seafood jampong
Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom. Cheese tokpokki

k73v09_9zmoCl7xULmjyeg.text: I am always wary of trendy Asian places - usually behind a veneer of trendy decor, the food is inauthentic and the prices are high.  This place definitely conformed to that - I ordered a dolsot bibimbap, which was unfortunately nothing to write home about.  It was the service here that reduced the star rating.  Our food took a very long time, and it was served in a staggered manner.  They messed up some of our orders, and one of our dishes came with a hair in it.  (my coworker hadn't reported it, but the kitchen came to apologize for it.... except she was apologizing on behalf of the wrong table).  I'm certain that this place will be popular for workers in the area, but they really need to step up the service/accuracy in this place before it will do well.  Also: this place does not offer takeaway!  Gasp!

poRLBWnkWKt2zzXcE46jMg.text: It's really not bad for a lunch box joint. They get 3 stars for the packaging and cute little stools and the bamboo utensils. Food is edible, like regular Lotte World supermarket lunch box towards end of the day quality. If i'm in the area again and starving I would definitely go again. Although I must say that for a place that's named kimchee... I wasn't very impressed with their kimchee...... -____-

Ai-hsnxW9OSJOZuighafWw.text: Again...Korean food truly fails in London. Just go to America or Korea for some real food.The chefs here are not even Korean...I ordered galbitang and it tasted like chicken broth with beef. No really flavor whatsoever. If you're visiting London I just suggest you don't come here. The building looks fancy, but the food is not. DON'T come here.

S2v1LGaHoxLcnShViomBLA.text: Called for a business lunch whilst working in London and was very impressed. Much of the seating is refectory-style shared benches, but the overall décor and ambience was good. This was my first experience of Korean food, but everything we had was flavourful and interesting. It wasn't like Chinese, or Japanese, it has a style of its own. Many of the dishes seem to have a spicy kick, but by no means all of them. One surprising thing was that both my starter and main dish were both cold: I hadn't realised this when I ordered them. Recommended: I'll have to go back and try dinner...

iu1Qo__vgOYXkp3anCwNCw.text: Step aside mojitos, move over margaritas and make room for exclusive Korean cocktails at the brand new KIMCHEE Bar!

photos.caption: Photo of Kimchee - London, United Kingdom

AklxLaG4__3UnNDFsvWXtQ.text: This is a very nice Korean place on High Holborn. Very tasty food (try the raw beef bibimbap in the hot stone pot and the seafood pancakes "Pa Jeon"), and prices are really moderate - mains are around 10£. Can get very busy during lunchtime.

w2DCnqUEKpdZo_CODxQhgg.text: Having worked in the area for a while, Kimchee is typically referred to as a landmark with the description, That Korean place that always has the queues out the front. If you have the good fortune of spending any time inside, the reason for the queues becomes abundantly clear.It's really, really good.I'll readily confess that I didn't really notice the names of all the dishes and drinks that were flying around the table, but that's possibly no bad thing and you could have quite an interesting evening from just randomly pointing and ordering from the selection available in this consciously Korean place. I know we had the eponymous fermented cabbage speciality, Kimchee, which was simultaneously weird and compelling, and made for an excellent component to more familiar menu options such as fried chicken bits, and a sort of pancake/omelette thing with seafood mixed through it. My personal star tip is for the steak tartare, which was nothing short of stunning and not at all what I expected.We were lucky enough to pair each group of plates with a Korean drink  such as a fermented rice milk drink and a plum-based spirit. Quite a departure from what the Western palate's familiar with, and though I'd hesitate to order any of them alone they too provided a fascinating contrast & counterpoint to the cuisine.Based on the fact Kimchee doesn't take reservations (although the queue turnover is quite rapid) it'd probably be a handy and different option for small groups with a good sharing mentality. The bench-style seating (think Wagamama) probably rules it out for an intimate dinner for 2, but it's keenly priced options make it handily informal. The owners have gone to incredible attention to detail with the decor, plates and glassware, and this all adds to give the place a busy informality without falling into cheap, cheerful & chaotic.As well as being my first run at Korean food, this was also my first VIQ event  two serves of massive luck in one!Based purely on personal preference I found the cocktails and alcoholic drinks to be a lot sweeter than I'd customarily drink, but am very eager to head back and explore some of the main dishes: from what we got to taste, it's easily worth a 20 minute queue.

oS23rkO4SYCWDu4PeeyC2Q.text: Don't go here for your regular Chicken Katsu Udon  go for an adventure in Korean cuisine. Apparently there's no major culinary differences between North and South Korea except that the latter use wholewheat rather than buckwheat flower?! Though I'd be very surprised if you could get anywhere near the quantity and quality of food in the whole North as you do in this lovely South Korean restaurant in Holborn, even if you were called Kim and were born into the ruling family. And I learned that if you really did want to eat the best of Korean food surrounded by brutalist 70s architecture you always try one of a dozen restaurants in New Malden. On the other hand if you want a cool candle-lit relaxing ambience which mixes modern furnishing with trad touches you can do a lot worse that find a suitable spot in Kimchee, depending on whether you're a single, couple or group, and whether it's for business or pleasure; Adam the genial general manager reckons it's much more fun in a group either way and if you want to make a party up that's culturally representative of this clientele you'd need to be 30% Korean.Seafood here offers the tastiest and most innovative dishes: Prawn Mari, Pa Jeon (octo-squid) and Crab 'sticks' were faboluous. The meat's very fresh and nicely spiced  try the dish in a steak tartare type pile with sesame seeds. The veggie options seemed to need hotter spice to make them interesting but I always think that. Drink each course down with a pretty plum wine or Korean non-fatal vodka. Indeed, on the basis of the food alone, mine would have been a five star rating. The cocktails were certainly very SWEET for me, not that one can complain when you are offered so many, and my feminist friend even told me afterwards that I appeared to be really enjoying the pink girly one. Now, of course, I wasn't.

6GQsUlYwpg1OUEsVDNYvVg.text: Their food wasn't terrible. But I'm not sure I would call it Korean food either.. if you're looking for authentic tasting Korean food, I would go across the street to Asadal (just around the corner, south, on Kingsway).  I thought for the price, the food was mediocre in taste and lacking in quantity. Kimchee is the kind of place you would like if you're also a fan of places like Ping Pong dim sum... Very westernized asian food. For a restaurant named kimchee, they really should spend some time to make their kimchi better. The restaurant is also very noisy. I went around sometime in May 2011.

wDi-zUO6lTs6e2cxXTFRNg.text: i went to Kimchee for the first VIQ event, and what a perfect place to set the standard for future events. From the moment you walk in and take in the beautiful wooden interior you feel transported somewhere far away. We sat in the what i can only describe as a tranquility section and was thentaken downstairs to the new floor which will be opened to the public soon and will add another 100+ seats. We were welcomed by the manager and head bartender and they told us about Kimchee and what the evening had in store. We sampled various Koreen dishes with wines to match: Seol Jung Mae (14% plum wine) this reminded me a little of sherry and was served with Prawn Mari a rice paper filled with prawns,rice and veg and a mustard dipping. The taste was fresh and an excellent starter. A tastier and healthier alternative to a spring roll.Bek Seju (rice based wine with ginseng and herbs)  a refreshing wine this was served with Pa Jeon a seafood pancake (this was filled with plump pieces of seafood) This was nothing like i expected, it reminded me of a fritatta  i can happly recommend this dish.Makgeolli (fermented rice milk) this is a very popular drink but not for me this came with several dishesdeep fried soft shell crab, gogi mandu (chicken dumplings) and Kimchee Jeon (cabbage pancakes)The Kimchee Jeon were very tasty and my favourite dish in this section though i must point out i enjoyed all the dishes!We were then served Kimchee which they make on the premises from scratch  pickled cabbage with a chilli paste  this wasnt to my taste but we were with a real kimchee enthusiast in our midst who said it was one of the best she had tasted so it must have been good.Out came a plate of Yuk Hwae (steak tartare to you and me) i couldnt bring myself to sample this as i like my meat well done but everyone else seemed to love it and the manager told us it was one of there popular dishes.Out came a rice paper basket filled with chicken Kanpoongi  a mouth watering deep fried chilli chicken in garlic sauce.We were then given 2 cocktails Bora blue (blueberry liquer mixed with Soju crushed ice and fresh blueberries) and Kimberry Makageoldi (a raspberry liquer based)finally to end the evening we were given a shot of Soju a Korean clear spirit.This was my first taste of Korean food and wow i was impressed. I have promised to take my husband here and i have a inkling of some of the dishes to order. A big thankyou to Kimchee for an excelllent night and Qype for introducing me to yet another tasty cuisineThe quality of food and surroundings would make you think that the prices would be high but they are not so i can 100% recommend this place for any occasion

_E_n8mYrQC9c-MbY_8Tueg.text: Certainly not a big fan of Asian food, but this place made me rethink. Its nicely decorated, makes you feel that you really are somewhere in Asia, in this case in Korea. I love how the decoration is mixed with modern and authentic items. The menu offers so much things that I cant decide where to begin from and I really do want to give everything a try. The service is fairly slow, but its worth the wait. The servers are friendly and smiley. The prices are affordable, nothing overpriced really. I recommend this place!

sIWED-ncy2uvxQ_Krf5G0Q.text: Really poor service. 10 waiters stood around but no one would seat me at a table, or to take my orders afterwards. One of them walked past behind me while I was waving to get attention and he ignored me (I am 100% certain he saw me) until I said "excuse me" loud enough for 2 tables either side to hear me. He thn signalled to say he would be back but he never did.

WQWFz5n2mOJAtCJ74iFdrA.text: Firstly, regarding some of the reviews below, sometimes i feel that people who have a bad experience rush to post negative comments on a portal such as this - which don't get me wrong every restaurant can have an off day. I can't help but think of how disproportionate this is, when so many more have great meals and don't post. Anyhoo, for me this place wins every time. Innovative, flavoursome, beautifully presented food at very reasonable prices. Showcasing the length and depth of the Korean food spectrum, all served in a sleek and bustling setting. The waiting staff are attentive, considering how busy the place actually is and informative. With such high turnover of customers, not everyone can be serviced 10/10 all of the time. Just don't let that ever put you off for this place is a real find and one I recommend time and time again.

oh73P2lTSHXmih502l7upA.text: Bulgolgi was delicious! Portions weren't huge, but the price isn't too bad.

O_FiDtWecE8TJdmTLoCr5w.text: Nice atmosphere, very lively and energetic. More like fast food korean than authentic experience. Bulgogi portions are tiny and the cook at the grill was burning everything. No quality control. The noodles were bland and bibimbap  was lacking in flavor of any kind. We were hoping for more...

JgUC-vqGNNYrgwtrNDqttg.text: The food honestly is quite good. It's also a chain, so you have consistent quality, and I do always enjoy my meal. It's definitely a solid option for this area of town and a step up from some of the nearby eateries. The only downfall is that service is incredibly spotty, especially if you're dining solo or in a small group. More often than not I do takeaway because dining in is simply too much of a hassle. Not sure about about authenticity, but it's worth a stop if you're around and need a full meal, especially on Sundays when the center shuts down.

Ed6qf1EdoOYVqcugbVVHcg.text: finally, a great korean restaurant outside of korea! and very reasonable price, and posh atmosphere. kimchi jeon was excellent. jajang was good too, definitely am coming back here

fIDXDQccihspMty8JgZeeQ.text: For photos - please go to chopstix2steaknives.blog…  Kimchee is a new restaurant that opened up in Holborn. It took over the ex-Matsuri site that had a fire incident last year which it seems that they never managed to recover from. It was another ladies' catch up dinner and the opening of Kimchee was perfect timing. On the day we went, it was actually Opening Day 2. Even at 8pm, the place was jam packed and we waited for 40 minutes to get a table. While waiting, there was a gentleman who asked if he could join us. Sorry mister, ladies only and trying to cut the queue is a no no! When you get to the front of the queue, a lady kindly invited us to wait inside at a scenic garden patch of stone pebbles and fountain with a wall of Korean characters glowing against a dark setting. Turn your head and you are greeted by the grill section where you could see the chefs busily grilling away. We were finally called and upon being seated, we were informed that any skewers orders will take around 20 minutes due to how busy the kitchen was. We quickly placed our orders as most of us were starving by then. While waiting for our orders, we looked around and it was a huge place. I almost did not notice that there were 2 sections to the place that had a cage like wall dividing both sections. Most tables have seats of 6 with bar-like benches along the side for lone or double diners. I liked the decor with the lanterns motif used for the lights; the whole place had a streamlined unassuming posh feel to it. Korean tea/green tea (per pot) - It was quite amusing when our drinks arrived as the Korean tea came in a huge earthen pot that looked like those Chinese clay pots used to boil herbal soup. Kimchee - The crunchy texture and sweetness of the cabbage is more prominent in this version with the heat of the chilli hitting you only right at the end. Not overly spicy which is good for the non-kimchee lovers but bad if you like it super spiced! Sukju Namul - A cold dish of bean sprouts in sesame oil & garlic dressing. This was quite normal and a good one to order if you like bean sprouts. On a side note, I'm quite used to having side dishes given automatically to each table free in Sydney and other countries that should all these side appetisers really be charged and accepted in London? Yuk Hwae - One of my favourites in Korean cuisine. Yuk Hwae comprises of thinly sliced raw beef that is semi-frozen with pears that have been sliced to the same length and size as the beef to bring out the refreshing sweetness. Topped with sesame sauce and egg yolk to give an aromatic creamy balance. The Yuk Hwae was one of the better ones I've had in London. It is such an amazing summer dish when made right. The one from Kimchee was good, the sweetness of the pear slices paired well with the beef. The dressing was light with just the right amount of sesame to accentuate the flavours. The beef slices could have been set to a more semi-frozen state so that it gives that crunchy texture but this is just nitpicking here. I am already happy that I did not get one that has been drowned in sesame (so many places do that) such that you don't get all the other elements that make this so good. Jap Chae - I really like the Jap Chae in Asadal which is quite close by, actually that was our Plan B if we couldn't get in to Kimchee. We all loved the Jap Chae here. Sesame oil and soy sauce that has clinged to each and every strand of glass vermicelli noodles, delicious! Pa Jeon - There were 3 Korean pancakes on the menu but we decided to go for the traditional version which is made with spring onions and seafood mix, served with soy and chilli sauce on the side. The pancake was too doughy and it didn't have that slight crisp exterior. The flavours were drowned out by the too generous proportion of the doughy batter. Spicy calamari - Spicy calamari was quite ordinary. The calamari itself was good but the batter was not deep fried enough and was a tad bland. The vegetables that came with it were good though. Crab Tuigim - This was quite a disappointment. Deep fried soft shell crab should be crispy with the oil mixed into the juices of the crab and batter for that oh-so-good deep fried taste. Kimchee's version was not deep fried enough and the soft shell crab was still quite fresh because of that. None of us liked this one. Bulgogi - Bulgogi is another favourite that people like to order and we were no exception. Described as thinly sliced beef that has been marinated in a blend of fruits, soy sauce, sesame oil, black pepper, onions and garlic, this was GOOD! Tenderly soft and juicy. Scallop skewer - The scallop had a slight stringy texture and charred exterior from being grilled while it was still semi-soft in the middle. The sauce was really good and more should have been given as what we got was not enough to bring out the taste. I recommend that you try to mop up every bit of that sauce with your
